English Latin Greek April 8, 2003 Christopher W. Blackwell markup Fixed tagging and ref to DTD November 24, 2002Christopher W. Blackwell Tagging November 10, 2002Christopher W. Blackwell Initial Markup Din. 1

(Dinarchus’ Against <name type="person">Demosthenes</name>; see also Oratory). This is a speech written by Dinarchus for client (whose name we do not know) prosecuting Demosthenes in a case involving bribery. In 324 BCE, Harpalus, who was Alexander the Great’s treasurer, fled from Babylon and came to Athens with a large amount of Alexander’s money. He was admitted into the city, taken into custody with the money, but later escaped. Afterwards, it was found that several hundred talents was missing from the money he had brought to the city. The Areopagus investigated the matter, and issued a report, or apophasis (a)pofa/sis), saying that certain Athenians had accepted bribes from Harpalus. Demosthenes was named in the report. Source: Ian Worthington, A Historical Commentary on Dinarchus: Rhetoric and Conspiracy in Late Fourth-Century Athens (University of Michigan Press, Ann Arbor, 1992).
